title: How to know if a book is copyrighted - Quora

response.answer_text: Was it first published in the U.S. after 1977? (More exactly, after 12:01 a.m. on January 1, 1978; that’s when the 1976 Copyright Act took effect.) Then it’s copyrighted. No printed notice is required. Was it first published in the U.S. before 1923? Then it’s out of copyright and in the public domain. Was it first published in the U.S. after 1961, and it has a copyright notice? Then it’s copyrighted. Was it first published in the U.S. between 1923 and 1978, and it doesn’t have a copyright notice? Then in theory the copyright is void, but you had better check very carefully. This a gray area. Was it first published in the U.S. between 1923 and 1961, and has a copyright notice? You need to check with the Copyright Office to find out if the copyright was renewed. Some were, some weren’t. If it was never published in the U.S. and the author died before 1947, it’s out of copyright. If it was never published in the U.S. and the author is still alive or died after 1947, it’s copyrighted. If it’s unpublished and you can’t determine when the author died, or if it’s owned by a corporation instead of an individual, the cut-off is 1922 instead of 1947. (Yes, that’s a year earlier than a published book — for the next seven months. Then they’ll sync up on 1923.) If it was published outside the U.S. but not in the U.S. and you can’t determine when the author died, or if it’s owned by a corporation instead of an individual, the cut-off is 1923 instead of 1947. I think that covers everything. I’m not 100% certain on the last few cases; if you really need to know for those, talk to an expert. If this seems complicated, it is — the U.S. reworked its copyright laws at least three times in the twentieth century, and because they didn’t permit changing the status of an existing work — that is, nothing in the public domain could ever be put under copyright again, or vice versa — there are a lot of lingering complexities. If it’s any comfort, by 2073 they should all be gone.

All works are automatically copyrighted when they are published. If it is not beyond the legal expiration limit for copyright, and there is no notice specifying its status as public domain, you should assume it is copyrighted unless the rights holder tells you otherwise.
